page.title: 14MOORLANDS NATURE RESERVE
page.content: The area is very flat and low - lying. It consists of nine cultivated fields. Of these, five are pasture and grazing land, for sheep, horses and cattle. The remaining four are planted with sugar beet, wheat and barley. The fields are bordered by hedges, mainly if hawthorn with some well established tress growing in them. A small stream in a deep ditch runs north - south in the east of the area. The ditch is overgrown with nettles, plantain, cow parsley, rosebay willow herb and grasses. The one farm in the area is Hill Moor Farm. It is situated by a small county road running diagonally from the south east corner of the area. In the south of the area is part of Moorlands Nature Reserve, a wooded area which is open to the public. Electricity pylons cross the area.
